Application_Facts: Applicant claimed refugee status due to alleged persecution in Kenya
Misrepresentation_Element: Negative credibility findings based on implausible testimony and inconsistencies
Evidence_Used: Board considered evidence submitted within procedural timelines
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to submit relevant evidence on time
Credibility_Assessment: Credibility issues based on plausible inferences and inconsistencies in testimony
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of Refugee Appeal Division decision
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of negative credibility finding and referral back for re-determination
Decision_Rationale: No reviewable error; Board applied correct legal standard and made reasonable credibility assessment
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Federal Court

Violation_Type: Refusal of protection based on risk assessment
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) - Protection obligations
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed risk of persecution in Turkey due to Kurdish ethnicity and political activities; PRRA officer assessed new evidence including a lawyer's letter and country reports
Claimant_Status: Protected Person or Applicant for Pre-Removal Risk Assessment (PRRA)
Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged inconsistency in applicant's evidence regarding arrests and involvement
Procedural_Issue: PRRA officer may have unreasonably dismissed key evidence (lawyer's letter on 1998 arrest)
Evidence_Used: Lawyer's letter confirming 1998 arrest, UK country report on treatment of activist Kurds, applicant's statements on political involvement
Evidentiary_Deficiency: PRRA officer found applicant's evidence unpersuasive; lack of corroboration on arrest claims
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's credibility questioned regarding past arrests and level of political activism
Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; decision upheld despite error on one factual finding
Relief_Sought: Protection under PRRA due to risk of persecution, torture, or cruel and unusual treatment
Remedy_Sought: Quashing of PRRA decision and referral back for re-determination
Legal_Standard_Applied: Whether the PRRA officer's decision was reasonable under the standard of reasonableness
Decision_Rationale: Even if the finding on the 1998 arrest was unreasonable, the overall conclusion stands as arrests alone do not constitute persecution; country evidence indicates harassment but not systematic persecution

Crime_Name: Immigration-related offences under the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Ms. Behrooznia provided new evidence of political involvement after her refugee hearing; Officer dismissed it without adequate consideration, conflating past and new activities.
Procedural_Issue: Failure to properly consider new evidence; lack of procedural fairness
Evidence_Used: New evidence of post-hearing political involvement
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer did not adequately assess credibility or materiality of new evidence
Credibility_Assessment: Officer questioned credibility but failed to provide reasoned analysis
Remedy_Sought: Remittal to a different PRRA Officer
Decision_Rationale: Decision was unreasonable due to inadequate consideration of new evidence

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness and procedural fairness of PRRA Officer's decision
Credibility_Assessment: Officer found some evidence insufficiently credible
Evidence_Type: Evidence related to risks based on religion, gender, and political involvement
Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution due to religion, gender, and political opinion
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Use of fraudulent travel documents; sufficiency and novelty of evidence
Proceeding_Type: Pre-Removal Risk Assessment (PRRA) and subsequent judicial review
Application_Error: Failure to recognize new evidence on political involvement
Evidence_Ignored: New evidence of political involvement submitted post-refugee hearing
Application_Factor: Presence of fraudulent documents and claimed risk upon return
Document_Fraud: Applicant arrived in Canada using fraudulent travel documents

Application_Facts: Dispute over validity of Band Council election results; alleged destruction of ballots; conflicting evidence on whether an appeal was filed under Customs Election Regulations
Procedural_Issue: Plaintiffs moved to strike defendants' counterclaim under Rule 401(c) based on unexhausted statutory remedies
Jurisdictional_Issue: Whether Federal Court has jurisdiction if statutory remedies are not exhausted; election disputes involving federal boards fall under federal jurisdiction if remedies are inadequate or exhausted
Evidence_Used: Alleged filing of appeal under Customs Election Regulations
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Conflicting evidence regarding the existence and adequacy of the appeal
Decision_Outcome: Motion to strike out counterclaim dismissed
Outcome: Case allowed to proceed to trial; factual disputes on appeal filing and remedy adequacy to be resolved at trial
Relief_Sought: Declaration in Federal Court regarding election validity
Remedy_Sought: Defendants seek to avoid exhaustion requirement due to inadequacy of statutory remedies
Legal_Standard_Applied: Federal Court jurisdiction applies if statutory remedies are exhausted or inadequate
Decision_Rationale: Issue of whether appeal was filed and whether remedies are adequate must be resolved at trial; defendants may proceed without exhaustion if remedies are inadequate

Violation_Type: Procedural errors in humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) assessment
Failure to consider evidence of hardship
Legal_Provision_Violated: Humanitarian and Compassionate (H&C) provisions under IRPA
Procedural fairness in PRRA and H&C decisions
Application_Facts: Evidence of past suffering in Kenya not considered
Negative H&C and PRRA decisions challenged
Applicants are returning residents facing hardship upon return to Kenya
Claimant_Status: Permanent Residents applying for H&C relief
Residency_Compliance: Compliant with residency obligations prior to departure
Procedural_Issue: Separate judicial review applications filed for each family member
Applications reviewed together despite procedural limitations
Evidence_Used: Evidence of past persecution and suffering in Kenya
Evidentiary_Deficiency: H&C decision failed to consider key evidence of hardship
Mischaracterization of facts regarding family members
Decision_Outcome: H&C decision set aside due to reviewable errors
PRRA decision upheld due to lack of new evidence
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of negative H&C and PRRA decisions
Permission to remain in Canada on humanitarian grounds
Remedy_Sought: Recognition of hardship upon return to Kenya
Decision_Rationale: H&C decision contained factual errors and failed to properly assess hardship
PRRA decision reasonable as no new evidence was presented

Application_Facts: Applicant was absent for 551 days, retained business ties in Colombia, and traveled frequently
Residency_Compliance: Failed to meet 1095-day physical presence requirement over 4 years
Evidence_Used: Record of absences (551 days), business ties in Colombia, travel history, Koo factors assessment
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient demonstration of primary connection to Canada
Credibility_Assessment: Absences viewed as a life pattern, not temporary; weak Canadian connections
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of citizenship judge's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Koo factors for assessing residency intent
Decision_Rationale: Judge reasonably concluded applicant did not meet residency requirement based on duration and pattern of absences and lack of strong ties to Canada

Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 14 of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Governing_Law: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Application_Facts: Translator made significant errors affecting credibility determinations, including mistranslations about border crossing and educational background; applicant was unaware of errors during hearing.
Procedural_Issue: Inadequate translation during refugee hearing undermining procedural fairness
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Significant translation errors not corrected during hearing
Credibility_Assessment: Errors affected the Board's credibility findings
Legal_Standard_Applied: Right to adequate translation under Section 14 of the Charter
Decision_Rationale: Translation errors were significant and undermined procedural fairness, even if they did not directly alter key findings; applicant could not waive rights due to lack of awareness.
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Refugee Protection Division (RPD)

Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Violation_Type: Failure to provide corroborating evidence for refugee claim
Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA - Definition and requirements for Convention refugee and person in need of protection
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed persecution due to forced marriage and inter-faith relationships in Liberia
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of Panel's decision on refugee status
Evidence_Used: Applicant's testimony, country condition reports on Liberia, Nigeria, and Ghana
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of supporting documentation on forced marriages in Liberia
Credibility_Assessment: Testimony found credible but undermined by lack of corroboration
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; Panel's decision upheld
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a Convention refugee or person in need of protection
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of the Panel's negative decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution under IRPA
Decision_Rationale: Lack of documentation on forced marriages in Liberia supports negative credibility inference despite credible testimony

Legal_Issue: Did the Member err in finding no jurisdiction to reconsider danger and appearance findings?
Outcome: The application is granted, the matter is remitted for reconsideration.
Basis_of_Claim: Detention based on deportation order and possession of a fraudulent passport
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Member incorrectly believed prior decisions stood until overturned by the Federal Court
Application_Error: Failure to recognize obligation to conduct a fresh review at each hearing
Legal_Standard: ID must decide afresh if continued detention is warranted at each hearing
Decision_Outcome: Remitted for reconsideration by a different ID Member

Risk_Assessment: Danger to the public and flight risk

Crimes.Crime_Name: Serious criminality under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Kippax detained since January 2013 due to serious criminality and deportation order
Jurisdictional_Issue: Member's misunderstanding of jurisdiction to reconsider prior findings
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to reassess danger and appearance risks
Decision_Outcome: Application granted, matter remitted for reconsideration
Outcome: Remanded for new hearing before different ID Member
Legal_Standard_Applied: Fresh assessment required at each detention review
Decision_Rationale: Member erred in law by not recognizing duty to reconsider

Legal_Issue: Did the Member err in finding no jurisdiction to reconsider danger and appearance findings?
Decision_Outcome: Application granted, matter remitted for reconsideration
Legal_Rule: ID must decide afresh at each hearing whether detention is warranted
Grounds_for_Claim: Erroneous belief that prior findings remain binding until overturned

Application_Facts: Applicant fled Mexico due to threats and assaults after reporting a drug transaction; reported incidents to authorities but received no protection
Procedural_Issue: Board Member incorrectly applied the legal standard by focusing on Mexico’s efforts rather than actual effectiveness of protection
Evidence_Used: Applicant's testimony, reports of threats and assaults, lack of response from Mexican authorities
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to assess effectiveness of state protection in Mexico
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim rejected by Board Member
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; decision set aside
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a refugee in Canada
Remedy_Sought: Re-determination of refugee claim by a different Board Member
Legal_Standard_Applied: Balance of probabilities; adequacy and effectiveness of state protection
Decision_Rationale: Board failed to properly assess whether state protection was actually effective in Mexico; focus should be on effectiveness, not just existence of efforts
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Protection Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board
